text: good morning today we will be learning
about what is hemoglobin a1c which is a
diabetes test so you have diabetes you
go to a doctor or you have your dad
grandmom you take them to the doctor and
the doctors like what have you been
doing your a1c is way out of control
your diabetes is way out of control
and you're like oh my god the past two
weeks have been following a strict
diabetic diet and my sugars are all have
been perfect then why's the doctor
saying my diabetes is out of control
so to understand that let's know what
the hemoglobin a1c is so we all have
little cells called red blood cells in
our body which contain a substance
called hemoglobin the work of this
hemoglobin is when you breathe in oxygen
to attach to the oxygen and take oxygen
to different cells and supply oxygen to
different cells so as our brain cells
the red blood cells also thrive on
glucose so the only form of energy for
your red blood cells as blood glucose so
whenever there's glucose in the blood
the RBC kind of is exposed to it or
takes a part of it and kind of stores in
it because that's its form of energy and
the RBC or your red blood cell lives 90
days or three months so when we do the
hemoglobin a1c test we are checking the
glucose in the RBC so that will give us
a range of how your blood sugar has been
in the past three months rather than an
instantaneous value which is your blood
glucose so to give an example this is
like instead of asking you like what is
your fasting blood sugar yesterday or
what did you have for dinner that's kind
of like an instantaneous value but
instead of that asking someone who has
been with you over the past three months
like your spouse or someone else and
have been silently watching you munch
all these sugary stuff and kind of
making a note and asking them about how
your diabetic diet has been over the
past three months so kind of think like
your red blood cell is the silent
spectator in your blood
who's been watching your blood glucose
trends even when you are not realizing
and that's what we are checking to kind
you know how your blood sugar range has
been over the past three months rather
than one instantaneous value so to give
you some noms
a normal hemoglobin a1c is somewhere
between like four and five point six
when you're in the five point seven to
six point four range you are a
pre-diabetic meaning you have a very
high risk of developing diabetes and
when you're over six point five or
higher then you are actually a diabetic
and when you have diabetes we'll have
targets for the a1c meaning it depends
mostly on your age and your other risk
factors but predominantly we try to
reach a goal of seven to seven point
five or lower and that kind of gives a
good diabetes control so here is a chart
where it shows like the range of blood
sugar over three months and expected a1c
values meaning if your Sugar's have been
in the 150s this is your a1c if your
sugars have predominantly been in the
260s this is your a1c so that's where
this test is a really valuable test
because it kind of gives a range rather
than an instantaneous value but are two
things that I would like to discuss
which can affect your hemoglobin a1c so
one is like if you're binging at times
like during festival days during
holidays and then you're just fasting
before coming to your doctor your
fasting blood Sugar's over two weeks
might be perfect but your a1c is still
going to be high because of all those
binge days when you're silent spectator
has been watching you and the other
thing is if you're maybe like having
really light meals for breakfast and
lunch and you're just checking your
blood Sugar's then and then you're
binging your dinner and you're not
checking your blood sugar then again
your silent spectator is watching and
when we check your a1c we are going to
know about that so that's why this test
is important and it really helps in the
management of diabetic patients thank
you
